prop.head.label.name: Part
prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.label.name: Chapter
prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Effect of transfer order on transferor court

para.paratext: The entry of a transfer order essentially divests the transferor court of jurisdiction over a case. The transferor court is not authorized to decide motions pending before it and undecided at the time the transfer order is entered.[1] The Panel has recognized that it may consider the status of matters pending before the transferor court in timing its decision.[2] The Panel has recognized that comity may require deference to the status of matters in the transferor court, stating in one case:

On principles of comity, where appropriate, the Panel has in the past timed its actions and constructed its orders in a manner which will permit the transferor court (and Courts of Appeals if any are involved) to reach timely decisions on particular issues without abrupt, disconcerting, untimely or inappropriate orders of transfer by the Panel. This policy of comity has been followed in the past and will be followed in the future by the Panel.

The successful use of Section 1407 requires cooperation among the Courts and by the Panel in an atmosphere of trust, confidence, comity and good will. The Panel believes these conditions exist and will continue to exist.[3]

The entry of an order transferring the case leaves the transferor court without authority to enter further orders in the case. The transferor court is simply required to comply with the request for transfer of the file in the transferred action. The divestment of jurisdiction is complete.[4] The court where the action is pending at the time a transfer order is entered cannot consider even emergency matters submitted to it.[5]

The transferee court's authority does not depend on delivery of files by the transferor court; as soon as the transfer is ordered, the transferee judge has plenary powers to decide issues,[6] and they do not rely on any action of the transferor court.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.

See In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484, 495–96 (J.P.M.L. 1968). Cf. In re Flight Transp. Corp. Securities Litigation, 764 F.2d 515 (8th Cir. 1985) (transferor court under 28 U.S.C.A. § 1404(a) loses jurisdiction to consider further matters); Seltmann v. A.W. Chesterton Co., 2009 WL 361947 (N.D. Cal. 2009) (court lacks jurisdiction to consider pending motion).
The timing of entry of Panel decisions is discussed in § 5:54.
See In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484, 496 (J.P.M.L. 1968).
In re Phenylpropanolamine (PPA) Products Liability Litigation, 460 F.3d 1217, 1230 (9th Cir. 2006) (quoting this work with approval).
See Glasstech, Inc. v. AB Kyro OY, 769 F.2d 1574 (Fed. Cir. 1985).
See, e.g., In re Metoprolol Succinate Patent Litigation, 329 F. Supp. 2d 1368 (J.P.M.L. 2004).
